questions.text: What is the volume of the prostate in normal adult males? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20cc

 

Explanation:

 

The volume of the prostate in normal adult males is 20cc.

 

The volume of the prostate gland in normal adult males can vary depending on age and other factors. However, on average, the volume of the prostate gland in an adult male is around 20-30 cubic centimeters (cc) or milliliters (mL).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The typical volume of the prostate in a normal adult male is around 20cc

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

 

The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) is characterized by the excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the posterior pituitary gland or another source. This excessive release results in water retention and dilutional hyponatremia.

 

Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L: This option is incorrect. In SIADH, urinary sodium is typically high, usually greater than 40 mEq/L, due to the body's inability to excrete water appropriately, which leads to concentrated urine with high sodium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum sodium <135 mEq/L: This option is correct as SIADH commonly presents with hyponatremia (low serum sodium levels) due to the dilution of blood sodium by the retained water.


Option C. Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg: This option is correct. In SIADH, urine osmolality is typically high because the kidneys are concentrating the urine inappropriately due to the persistent effect of ADH.

 

Option D. Patient can be clinically euvolemic: This option is correct. Patients with SIADH often appear clinically euvolemic (normal body fluid volume), as the retained water is distributed evenly throughout the body without significant signs of fluid overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key fact to remember is that in SIADH, patients have high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L) due to the body's inability to excrete water properly, leading to concentrated urine.

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-apoptotic factor? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MCL 1

 

MCL 1 is an anti-apoptotic gene which prevents apoptosis by binding to and neutralizing pro-apoptotic proteins such as BAX and BAK. MCL1 plays a crucial role in resistance to chemotherapy drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PUMA: PUMA (p53 upregulated modulator of apoptosis) is a pro-apoptotic gene that is activated by p53 and plays a role in promoting apoptosis by inhibiting anti-apoptotic BCL-2 family members.

 

Option B. BAD: BAD is another pro-apoptotic protein that promotes apoptosis by binding to and inhibiting anti-apoptotic proteins such as BCL-2 and BCL-XL.

 

Option C. BAK: BAK is a pro-apoptotic protein that, when activated, oligomerizes and disrupts the mitochondrial membrane, leading to cytochrome c release and the activation of caspases, which are crucial for apoptosis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with weight loss, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and pleural effusion. Her HRCT shows a "tree-in-bud" pattern, indicating lung consolidation and effusion. Analysis of pleural fluid reveals high adenosine deaminase (ADA) levels with a predominance of lymphocytes. What is the most likely finding on lymph node biopsy? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Necrotizing epithelioid granuloma

 

This is a classic presentation of tuberculosis (TB):

 

  • "Tree-in-bud" appearance on HRCT indicates endobronchial spread — a hallmark of active pulmonary TB.
  • Mediastinal lymphadenopathy and pleural effusion with lymphocyte predominance further support a tuberculous etiology.
  • High ADA (>40 U/L) in pleural fluid is a strong indicator of TB pleuritis.

 

The most characteristic lymph node biopsy finding in TB is:

 

  • Necrotizing (caseating) epithelioid granulomas
  •  Composed of epithelioid cells (from activated macrophages), Langhans giant cells, and central caseous necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fungal hyphae surrounded by lymphocytes:  Seen in invasive fungal infections (e.g., aspergillosis, histoplasmosis), more common in immunocompromised individuals; not typically associated with high ADA.

 

Option B. Anthracosis pigment: Black carbon pigment in lungs/lymph nodes from pollution or smoking. Not pathological in itself and doesn’t cause systemic symptoms or effusion.

 

Option D. Reactive hyperplasia: Seen in viral or nonspecific bacterial infections. No granulomas or caseation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young woman with systemic symptoms, tree-in-bud pattern, lymphocytic pleural effusion, and high ADA, TB is the most likely diagnosis. The hallmark histopathological finding is a necrotizing epithelioid granuloma.

choices.text: TACE is used for multinodular lesions
Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm
The incidence of HCC is increasing
NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC

questions.text: Identify the false statement out of the following: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm

 

Lenvatinib is used to treat advanced stages of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Treatment of lesions less than 3 cm is wide excision or liver transplant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TACE is used for multinodular lesions: True. TACE (Transarterial chemoembolization) combined with other treatments is used for unresectable multiple nodular and massive HCC, especially when a single nodular diameter is greater than 5 cm (intermediate or advanced HCC).

 

Option C. The incidence of HCC is increasing: True. The incidence of HCC is increasing worldwide due to the increase in HCV and HBV infections, along with lifestyle disorders like obesity.

 

Option D. NASH (Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis) and NAFLD (Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease) are risk factors for HCC: True. Obesity is associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NALD), which progresses to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) causing cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Thus, NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Barcelona-Clinic-Liver Cancer (BCLC) Classification is the commonly used staging system for HCC.
  • Very early HCC is treated by ablation, early HCC with a single nodule is resected, and when there are multiple nodules over 3 cm, ablation or transplantation are considered.
  • Intermediate stage HCC is treated by chemoembolization, and TACE (Trans-arterial chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions.
  • Advanced stages of the disease with macrovascular invasion are treated with systemic therapies. Lenvatinib and sorafenib are first-line drugs.
  • Supportive care is given at the terminal stage of the disease.

choices.text: Iron deficiency anemia
B12 deficiency
Hereditary spherocytosis
Acute myeloid leukemia

questions.text: What is your diagnosis with respect to the findings shown in the peripheral smear given below? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B12 deficiency

 

The peripheral smear provided shows the presence of macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. These findings are characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, which is most commonly caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate.

 

  • Macro-ovalocytes are large, oval-shaped red blood cells that result from impaired DNA synthesis, which occurs in megaloblastic anemia.
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils are neutrophils with more than the normal number of nuclear lobes (usually more than five). This is a classic finding in vitamin B12 or folate deficiency.

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to impaired DNA synthesis, causing ineffective erythropoiesis and resulting in the release of abnormally large red blood cells (macro-ovalocytes) and hypersegmented neutrophils into the circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: This typically presents with microcytic hypochromic red blood cells, not macro-ovalocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.

 

Option C. Hereditary spherocytosis: This condition is characterized by the presence of spherocytes (small, round, dense red blood cells) and not macro-ovalocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.

 

Option D. Acute myeloid leukemia: AML is characterized by the presence of blasts in the peripheral blood smear, which are immature white blood cells, not macro-ovalocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils in a peripheral smear is indicative of B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia.

choices.text: High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Nutritional Rickets? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

 

NUTRITIONAL RICKETS

 

  • In nutritional rickets, the calcium to creatinine ratio in urine is generally low instead of high. 

  • This occurs because rickets is the result of a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, resulting in inadequate mineralization of bone. 

  • In reaction to conserve calcium levels, the body elevates the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and the kidneys actively reabsorb calcium, resulting in low urinary excretion of calcium and phosphate. 

  • Thus, the ratio of calcium to creatinine in urine is not elevated in nutritional rickets, reflecting calcium conservation.

  • A high urine calcium to creatinine ratio would suggest hypercalciuria, which is characteristic of conditions like hyperparathyroidismwithout underlying vitamin D deficiency, or certain renal tubular disorders, but not nutritional rickets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal Serum Calcium: In nutritional rickets, vitamin D deficiency initially leads to decreased calcium absorption and a tendency for low serum calcium. This activates the compensatory mechanism of the body. The drop in serum calcium stimulates the parathyroid glands to release more parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH then acts to increase calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, and mobilizes calcium from the bones (resorption). This helps to maintain serum calcium levels within the normal range, at the expense of bone health. So, it is common to see normal serum calcium in many cases of nutritional rickets.

 

Option B. Elevated Parathyroid Hormone: In rickets, parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels are frequently increased (secondary hyperparathyroidism) as the body attempts to counteract low calcium levels by enhancing calcium resorption from bones and kidneys. This is a hallmark of nutritional rickets and is the body's attempt to maintain calcium homeostasis.

 

Option C. Low Serum Phosphorus: A key feature of nutritional rickets is decreased serum phosphorus resulting from compromised renal phosphate reabsorption, exacerbated by a deficiency of vitamin D. High levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) have a significant effect on phosphate metabolism. PTH causes the kidneys to excrete more phosphate in the urine. This leads to hypophosphatemia, which directly impairs the mineralization of new bone and cartilage, leading to the characteristic bone deformities of rickets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nutritional rickets is characterized by low vitamin D, leading to compensatory high PTH, which helps maintain normal serum calcium (often), but causes low serum phosphorus and, importantly, low urine calcium excretion due to renal calcium conservation.

  • A low UCa/Cr ratio is more commonly associated with nutritional rickets.

  • However, a high UCa/Cr ratio is not entirely uncommon and might reflect specific underlying mechanisms in some cases.

  • Therefore, the UCa/Cr ratio in nutritional rickets can vary depending on the specific situation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibitor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab

 

PCSK-9 inhibitors are a class of drugs that significantly lower LDL cholesterol levels by inhibiting the protein PCSK-9, which in turn increases the number of LDL receptors available to clear LDL cholesterol from the blood.

 

There are only 2 PCSK-9 inhibitors: Evolocumab and alirocumab. Among the options provided:

 

Evolocumab is a well-known PCSK-9 inhibitor used in modern clinical practice to manage hyperlipidemia, particularly in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or those who are at high risk of cardiovascular events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is an NPC1L1 transport inhibitor, also known as an intestinal cholesterol absorption inhibitor. It reduces blood cholesterol by decreasing the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine.

 

Option C. Evinacumab: Evinacumab is a newer drug that acts as an ANGPTL3 inhibitor. It is specifically approved for use in patients with familial homozygous type 2 hyperlipidemia.

 

Option D. Everolimus: Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor and an immunosuppressive drug used primarily in organ transplantation and certain types of cancer. It is not related to the treatment of dyslipidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Evolocumab is a PCSK-9 inhibitor used to significantly lower LDL cholesterol levels, particularly in high-risk patients.

choices.text: 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in smokers if smoking is eliminated
10% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated

questions.text: A 45-year-old researcher is keenly interested in understanding the relationship between lung cancer and smoking habits. After conducting an extensive study and analyzing his data, he finds that the attributable risk is 90%. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of this result? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

 

  • In the given scenario, the attributable risk of cigarette smoking to lung cancer is 90%; hence, 90% cases of lung cancer are due to smoking as a risk factor
  • The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed is given by the attributable risk.
  • Attributable risk is the difference in risk of disease between two groups (exposed and non-exposed) and represents the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Interpretation of AR (attributable risk): AR is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure
  • Interpretation of PAR (Population attributable risk): If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population

choices.text: Chronic Cocaine use
Subacute progression over 4 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT indicative of underlying serious pathology in headache? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic Cocaine use

 

While acute cocaine use can lead to serious complications such as intracranial hemorrhage, chronic cocaine use does not typically present as a headache warning sign for serious pathology unless associated with acute episodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age > 50: New onset headache in individuals over 50 years of age is a red flag and suggests the possibility of serious conditions such as giant cell arteritis or intracranial mass lesions.

 

Option B. Temporal tenderness: This is often a sign of temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis), a serious condition that can lead to blindness if not treated promptly.

 

Option D. Subacute progression over 4 weeks: This indicates a progressive condition such as a brain tumor or increased intracranial pressure, which are serious pathologies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic cocaine use is not typically indicative of a serious underlying pathology in headache unless associated with acute episodes.

 

Headache Symptoms That Suggest a Serious Underlying Disorder

 

  • Sudden-onset headache
  • First severe headache
  • "Worst" headache ever
  • Vomiting that precedes headache
  • Subacute worsening over days or weeks
  • Pain induced by bending, lifting, coughing
  • Pain that disturbs sleep or presents immediately upon awakening
  • Known systemic illness
  • Onset after age 55
  • Fever or unexplained systemic signs
  • Abnormal neurologic examination
  • Pain associated with local tenderness, e.g., region of temporal artery

questions.text:
Which of these is the definition of effective CPR?

 

  1. Respiratory rate: 20 - 24 breaths per minute.
  2. Chest compressions: 100-120/min.
  3. Allow complete chest recoil.
  4. 5-6 cm depression.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2, 3 and 4

 

Components of High-Quality CPR:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Effective CPR includes the following components:

 

  • Chest compressions: 100-120/min. This ensures that the heart is pumping enough blood to maintain circulation during cardiac arrest.
  • Allow complete chest recoil. Allowing the chest to fully recoil between compressions ensures that the heart fills adequately with blood between each compression, which is crucial for effective circulation.
  • 5-6 cm depression. The depth of chest compressions should be between 5-6 cm (2-2.4 inches) for adults. This depth is essential to create enough pressure to maintain circulation.

 

Other Option:

 

  1. Respiratory rate: 20-24 breaths per minute. This is not correct for effective CPR. The recommended respiratory rate during CPR is about 10-12 breaths per minute when an advanced airway is in place. Higher respiratory rates can lead to hyperventilation, which can be detrimental.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Effective CPR is characterized by chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute, allowing complete chest recoil, and compressing the chest to a depth of 5-6 cm.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2529-2534

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The median nerve supplies the 1st lumbrical which is marked.

 

The 1st lumbrical muscle is innervated by the median nerve. It is a small, quadrilateral muscle located in the hand that arises from the tendon of the flexor digitorum profundus muscle of the index finger and inserts into the extensor expansion of the index finger. Its main function is to flex the metacarpophalangeal joint of the index finger and extend the interphalangeal joints of the index finger. The 1st lumbrical muscle is named because it is associated with the first (index) finger, and there are a total of four lumbrical muscles in the hand - one for each of the four fingers (excluding the thumb).

 

The first and second lumbrical nerves are innervated by the median nerve. The third and fourth lumbricals are innervated by the deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial Nerve: The radial nerve primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand, including the wrist and finger extensors. It does not supply the lumbrical muscles.

 

Option C. Ulnar Nerve: The ulnar nerve supplies several intrinsic hand muscles, including the lumbrical muscles. However, the first lumbrical is typically innervated by the median nerve, as mentioned earlier.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous Nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve primarily innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm. It does not supply the lumbrical muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 1st lumbrical muscle of the hand is innervated by the median nerve is crucial for clinical assessments of hand function, especially in cases of nerve injury or compression syndromes like carpal tunnel syndrome, where the median nerve's functionality can be compromised.

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly associated with a hypercoagulable state? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor V mutation

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulability. It should be suspected in young patients (<50 years) presenting with thrombotic manifestations.

 

  • It is caused by substitution in the Factor V gene (Factor V Leiden mutation)
  • Causes enhanced coagulability in patients
  • In heterozygous condition, increases risk of thrombus formation by 4-5 times
  • In homozygous condition, increases risk by 50 times

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antithrombin III deficiency 

 

  • Although this can cause thrombosis, it is less common than Factor V Leiden mutation
  • Antithrombin III acts as a natural anticoagulant
  • Its deficiency is rarer compared to Factor V Leiden mutation

 

Option C. Factor XIII deficiency

 

  • Factor XIII is involved in clot stabilization
  • Its deficiency causes bleeding rather than thrombosis
  • Characterized by umbilical cord bleeding in newborns

 

Option D. Factor XII deficiency 

 

  • Factor XII initiates intrinsic pathway of coagulation
  • Its deficiency does not cause significant bleeding
  • Not typically associated with hypercoagulable states

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulable states, increasing thrombosis risk 4-5 times in heterozygous and 50 times in homozygous individuals.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman visits an infertility clinic. She has a regular 28-day cycle. How should she be evaluated? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum progesterone on day 21

 

Explanation:

 

For a woman with a regular 28-day cycle, serum progesterone is typically measured on day 21 to assess for ovulation. Progesterone levels on day 21 of the menstrual cycle provide information about whether ovulation has occurred.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Day 21 Progesterone Measurement: In a regular 28-day cycle, day 21 corresponds to the mid-luteal phase, about 7 days after ovulation. Progesterone levels peak during this time, and values above 10 ng/mL are indicative of ovulation.
  • Purpose: This test helps to determine if the cycles are ovulatory or anovulatory.

 

Other tests for ovulation:

 

  • Basal body temperature: A biphasic temperature pattern suggests ovulation.
  • Urinary LH kits (ovulation prediction kits): Ovulation occurs the day following the peak LH surge.
  • Endometrial biopsy: This can provide histological confirmation of ovulation.
  • Ultrasonography: Follicular tracking can visualize the growth and rupture of the follicle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum progesterone on day 14: Measuring progesterone on day 14 is not useful as it corresponds to the follicular phase when progesterone levels are low and not indicative of ovulation.

 

Option C. Serum LH on day 14: While an LH surge around day 14 can indicate impending ovulation, it does not confirm that ovulation has actually occurred.

 

Option D. Serum LH on day 21: Measuring LH on day 21 is not useful for assessing ovulation, as LH levels peak around mid-cycle and are not elevated during the luteal phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a woman with a regular 28-day menstrual cycle, measuring serum progesterone on day 21 is the appropriate method to evaluate for ovulation, with levels above 10 ng/mL indicating that ovulation has occurred.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg435

questions.text: What is the repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-homologous end joining

 

NHEJ is the primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9. When CRISPR-Cas9 induces double-strand breaks in DNA, NHEJ rejoins the broken DNA ends, often introducing insertions or deletions (indels) at the repair site. This can result in gene knockout or disruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision repair (BER): BER is a DNA repair mechanism that corrects damaged or mismatched bases in the DNA. It primarily deals with single-base changes and small DNA lesions. CRISPR-Cas9, on the other hand, creates double-strand breaks, so BER is not directly involved in repairing these breaks.

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair (NER): NER is another DNA repair mechanism that mainly deals with the removal of larger DNA lesions, such as those caused by UV radiation. It is not the primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9-induced double-strand breaks.

 

Option D. Mismatch repair (MMR): MMR is a repair mechanism that corrects errors in DNA replication, specifically base-pair mismatches and small insertion-deletion loops. It is not the primary mechanism involved in repairing double-strand breaks created by CRISPR-Cas9.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9 is non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), which repairs double-strand breaks by ligating the broken DNA ends, potentially causing insertions or deletions that disrupt the target gene.

questions.text:
What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image?

(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
✅ Correct Answer: B. Grade 2

📸 Image Analysis:

The otoscopic image shows a retracted pars tensa where deeper middle ear structures like the long process of the incus and incudostapedial joint are visible. The lateral process of the malleus is prominently seen, and the tympanic membrane appears pulled medially, but it is not adherent to the promontory, and air is still visible in the middle ear. This presentation is typical of Grade 2 retraction.

🔍 Explanation of Options:

Option A: Grade 1

In Grade 1 pars tensa retraction, there is only mild inward retraction. The cone of light is lost, the fibrous annulus appears more prominent, and the handle of the malleus becomes more medialized. Importantly, there is no contact with the ossicles, and ossicular landmarks like the incus are not visible. This does not match the findings seen in the image.

 

Option B: Grade 2

Grade 2 retraction is more severe than Grade 1, and the pars tensa is retracted to the extent that it touches the long process of the incus. Deeper structures like the incudostapedial joint, round window niche, and even the horizontal facial canal may be visible. The tympanic membrane still retains some mobility and is not adherent to the promontory. This fits the otoscopic image exactly, where ossicular structures are seen but no signs of complete adhesion are present.

 

Option C: Grade 3

In Grade 3 retraction, the tympanic membrane is severely retracted and becomes adherent to the promontory, forming what is called an atelectatic membrane. Although some air may still remain in the middle ear, the drum is essentially collapsed onto the medial wall. This condition is more advanced than what is seen in the current image.

 

Option D: Grade 4

This is the most severe stage where the entire tympanic membrane is stuck to the promontory, and there is complete loss of middle ear aeration. It often leads to adhesive otitis media, and ossicular erosion (such as necrosis of the incus) may occur. This is clearly not the case here, as ossicles are intact and the membrane is not fully adherent.

🧠 Educational Objective:

Grade 2 pars tensa retraction is identified when the tympanic membrane retracts to touch the long process of the incus without adhering to the promontory, often revealing middle ear ossicles such as the incudostapedial joint.

choices.text: Includes breathing, movements, tone, and Amniotic fluid volume
Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH
Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages
Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia

questions.text: All are true about biophysical profile (BPP) except? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages

 

Explanation:

 

  • BPP score is not inconsistent with fetal pH, but has a direct linear relationship with fetal pH and thus can be used to predict fetal acidemia.
  • BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency.
  • It consists of five components/ variables and the observations are made in a 30 minutes time period.
  • The Biophysical Profile has 5 components and is scored using Manning score
    • NST
    • Amniotic Fluid Volume
    • Fetal movement
    • Fetal Tone
    • Fetal Breathing

   

 

  • A low Manning score correlates with fetal hypoxia
  • Narcotics and sedatives can significantly lower the score
  • A BPP score of 0 was almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia, whereas a normal score of 8 or 10 was associated with normal pH.
  • An equivocal test result—a score of 6—was a poor predictor of an abnormal outcome. A drop in the BPP score from 2 or 4 down to 0 more accurately predicted an abnormal fetal outcome.
  • Overall, BPP scores provided poor sensitivity to predict cord blood pH
  • The Modified BPP has 2 components
    • NST
    • AFI

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Includes breathing, movements, tone, and Amniotic fluid volume: This statement is true. The BPP includes assessments of fetal breathing, movements, tone, and the Amniotic fluid volume as part of its evaluation.

 

Option B. Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH: This statement is true. The BPP score helps predict fetal outcome and provides an indication of fetal pH, reflecting the level of fetal distress.

 

Option D. Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia: This statement is true. A BPP score of less than 4 correlates with a fetal pH <7.2, and a score of 0 is almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Biophysical Profile (BPP) provides a consistent prediction of fetal pH and outcome, with a lower score correlating with increased risk of fetal acidemia.

 

Ref: Page no 999, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text: A neonate is found to have increased irritability, poor feeding, and 2 episodes of seizures. Lumbar puncture was done and the findings were suggestive of meningitis. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus agalactiae

 

  • Neonatal meningitis is suspected in the given clinical scenario. The most likely causative organism is Streptococcus agalactiae, which is part of group B streptococci.
  • Neonatal meningitis can either have an early or a late start. Late-onset meningitis affects premature infants and is typically caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci (primarily S. epidermidis), as well as S. aureus, E. coli, and Klebsiella species. Early-onset meningitis affects newborns within the first 72 hours of life.
  • Group B streptococci are the most common cause of both meningitis and neonatal sepsis, followed by E. coli. However, E. coli is the most common cause of early-onset sepsis and meningitis among very low birth weight infants (less than 1500 g).

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. Neisseria meningitidis: Asymptomatic meningococcal infections are common. If invasive disease occurs, the clinical spectrum ranges from meningococcal meningitis (which accounts for the majority of cases) to bacteremia without sepsis, meningococcal septicemia with or without meningitis, pneumonia, chronic meningococcemia, and occult bacteremia.

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes: Meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes is relatively rare but clinically significant. Infants acquire infection in utero or by inoculation through an infected birth canal. Neonatal listeriosis can be,

 

  • Early-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants less than 5 days old, usually within 1-2 days of birth. Predominantly septicemic form.
  • Late-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants >5 days old. Predominantly meningitic form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and early recognition and treatment are critical for reducing morbidity and mortality.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿ETDRS chart - Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study

questions.text: Identify the chart given in the picture below: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hess chart

 

  • Hess chart is a diagnostic tool used to assess the field of a binocular single vision.
  • It is used to diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus.
  • Incomitant strabismus is a type of squint that occurs due to the limitation of eye movement associated with paralytic or mechanical etiologies.
  • The chart consists of a smaller chart that indicates the eye with the paretic muscle and a larger chart that indicates the eye with an overacting muscle.
  • The field of binocular single vision is the area where bifoveal fusion of an object of interest occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: The Snellen chart is used to test visual acuity. Visual acuity is the eye's ability to discriminate between two points.

 

A picture of the Snellen chart is given below.

 

 

Option C: The Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity letter chart consists of letters of constant size but decreasing contrast. It is viewed by the patient from a distance of 1 meter until the lowest resolvable group of three letters on the chart is reached. It is used to measure contrast sensitivity, a measure of the ability to distinguish an object against its background. An image of the Pelli-Robson chart used in the Middle East is given below.

 

 

Option D: The early treatment diabetic retinopathy study or ETDRS chart presents a series of 5 letters of equal difficulty on each row, with standardized spacing between letters and rows. It consists of a total of 14 lines having 70 letters. It is also used to test visual acuity. An image of the ETDRS chart is given below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hess chart is specifically designed to assess binocular vision and ocular muscle function, especially useful in diagnosing and managing strabismus and similar conditions affecting eye alignment and movement.

questions.text: A young girl presents with retention of urine and cyclical abdominal pain. On examination, there is a tense bluish bulge seen at the introitus. The diagnosis is? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Imperforate hymen

 

An imperforate hymen is a congenital disorder where the hymen, a thin membrane that typically surrounds or partially covers the vaginal opening, completely obstructs the vaginal opening. This condition can lead to the accumulation of menstrual blood within the vagina (hematocolpos) and uterus (hematometra), resulting in cyclical abdominal pain and urinary retention due to pressure on the bladder.

 

The classic presentation includes:

 

  • Cyclical abdominal pain: This occurs as menstrual blood accumulates but cannot exit the body, leading to distension and discomfort.
  • Retention of urine: The accumulated blood can exert pressure on the bladder and urethra, causing difficulty in urination.
  • Tense bluish bulge at the introitus: This is a distinctive finding in imperforate hymen, where the accumulated blood stretches the hymen, causing it to appear bluish and bulging at the vaginal opening.

 

The treatment for an imperforate hymen typically involves making a cruciate incision in the hymen to drain the accumulated blood (hematocolpos) and relieve the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transverse vaginal septum: This condition involves a fibrous or muscular wall across the vagina, which can also cause symptoms similar to an imperforate hymen, such as hematocolpos and urinary retention. However, it does not usually present with the characteristic tense bluish bulge at the introitus because the septum is thicker and the blood does not push against the hymen.

 

Option C. Vertical vaginal septum: A vertical vaginal septum is a partition that divides the vaginal canal into two parts. While it may lead to reproductive issues or dyspareunia, it typically does not cause urinary retention or cyclical pain as described in this case, nor does it present with a bluish bulge.

 

Option D. Mullerian agenesis: This is a congenital absence of the uterus, cervix, and upper part of the vagina. Patients with this condition often present with primary amenorrhea but do not typically have cyclical abdominal pain or urinary retention. Additionally, there would be no bluish bulge at the introitus because there is no accumulation of blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of cyclical abdominal pain, urinary retention, and a tense bluish bulge at the introitus in a young girl strongly suggests an imperforate hymen. Early diagnosis and surgical intervention can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

questions.text: All of the following coagulation factors increase in pregnancy except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Factor XI

 

Pregnancy induces a hypercoagulable state to prepare the body for the increased risk of bleeding during delivery. This state is characterized by an increase in several coagulation factors, which enhances clot formation.

 

  • Factor II (Prothrombin): Increases during pregnancy. This contributes to a higher risk of clotting.
  • Factor VII: Increases during pregnancy, aiding in the clotting process.
  • Factor VIII: Also increases during pregnancy, enhancing clotting factors and overall coagulation.
  • Factor XI: Does not increase during pregnancy. In fact, Factor XI levels are slightly decreased in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor II: Factor II increases during pregnancy, contributing to the hypercoagulable state.

 

Option B. Factor VII: Factor VII levels increase during pregnancy, supporting the increased coagulation needed.

 

Option C. Factor VIII: Factor VIII increases during pregnancy, which is consistent with the overall increase in clotting factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor XI is the coagulation factor that does not increase during pregnancy and may actually decrease slightly.

 

Ref: Page no 508, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

1-b . Transthyretin (TTR) or Prealbumin is a tetrameric transport protein highly conserved through vertebrate evolution and synthesized in the liver, choroid plexus, and retinal pigment epithelium. TTR transports the thyroid hormone thyroxine and the retinol-binding protein (RBP) bound to retinol (vitamin A).

 

 2-c. Transcobalamins are carrier proteins which bind cobalamin (B12). Transcobalamin I (TCN1), also known as haptocorrin, R-factor, and R-protein, is a glycoprotein produced by the salivary glands of the mouth. It primarily serves to protect cobalamin (Vitamin B12) from acid degradation in the stomach by producing a Haptocorrin-Vitamin B12 complex. Once the complex has traveled to the more neutral duodenum, pancreatic proteases degrade haptocorrin, releasing free cobalamin, which now binds to intrinsic factor for absorption by ileal enterocytes. Transcobalamin II (TCN2) binds cobalamin once it has been taken up by enterocytes of the terminal ileum and the "Intrinsic Factor-Vitamin B12" complex has been degraded. Transcobalamin II is then involved with the transport of Vitamin B12 to the tissues.

 

 3-d. Haptoglobin (abbreviated as Hp) in blood plasma, haptoglobin binds with high affinity to free hemoglobin released from erythrocytes, and thereby inhibits its deleterious oxidative activity. 

 

4-a. Hemopexin binds to free heme. The haptoglobin-hemoglobin complex will then be removed by the reticuloendothelial system (mostly the spleen).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct pairs are as follows:

 

1. Thyroxine - b. Pre-albumin

2. Vitamin B12 - c. Transcobalamin

3. Hemoglobin - d. Haptoglobin

4. Heme - a. Hemopexin

choices.text: MRI showing < 1/3rd of MCA territorial infarct

questions.text: Thrombolysis can be considered in all of these conditions, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood pressure of > 185/110 mmHg

 

Blood pressure of > 185/110 mmHg: This is a contraindication for thrombolysis. Elevated blood pressure increases the risk of hemorrhagic complications during thrombolysis. Therefore, blood pressure must be controlled to below 185/110 mmHg before initiating thrombolytic therapy.

 

Thrombolysis is a treatment used to dissolve blood clots in certain types of stroke patients. It is most effective when administered within a specific time window from the onset of symptoms and under certain conditions to ensure patient safety and efficacy of the treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI showing < 1/3rd of MCA territorial infarct: This indicates that the infarct size is within a range that is generally considered safe for thrombolysis. More extensive infarcts (> 1/3rd of the middle cerebral artery territory) are a contraindication due to the higher risk of hemorrhagic transformation.

 

Option C. Ischemia < 2 hours and D. Onset of symptoms < 4 hours: Both of these options fall within the critical time window for thrombolysis, which is generally considered up to 4.5 hours from symptom onset. Treatment within this time frame can significantly improve outcomes in stroke patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thrombolysis is contraindicated in patients with blood pressure higher than 185/110 mmHg at the time of treatment.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis based on this X-ray?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patella fracture

 

  • The given image shows a comminuted patellar fracture with the fracture lines visible and moderate joint effusion.

 

 

PATELLA FRACTURE

 

  • Patellar fractures are usually caused by direct trauma, such as a fall from standing height onto the flexed knee or a dashboard impact from a motor vehicle collision.
  • These fractures can also be caused by rapid contracture of the quadriceps with a flexed knee that can lead to loss of the extensor mechanism.
  • Patella fractures account for 1% of all skeletal injuries and 6-9% are open fractures.
  • Male to female ratio is 2:1 and most fractures occur in 20-50 year olds.
  • On inspection, a palpable patellar defect, significant hemarthrosis, and lacerations, abrasions in setting of open fractures are found.
  • The patient has an inability to perform straight leg raise.
  • The extensor mechanism and retinaculum are disrupted.
  • Lateral view radiograph is the best view for transverse fractures. It is obtained in 30⁰ knee flexion.

 

Lateral view showing effusion in the knee

 

  • Axial view is the best view for vertical fractures.

 

 

  • An important differential diagnosis of patellar fracture is bipartite patella which can be mistaken as patella fracture. It shows smooth and regular borders on the radiograph; can be bilateral in 50% cases, and is characteristically seen in superolateral position.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibial Condyle fracture: Tibial Plateau fractures are periarticular injuries of the proximal tibia frequently associated with soft tissue injury. Incidence is 1-2% of all fractures. It can be caused in males in age group of 40s due to high energy trauma, and in females of age group of 70s due to low energy falls. Incidence of lateral plateau fracture is 70-80% (due to valgus load), bicondylar is 10-30% (due to axial load), and of medial plateau is 10-20% (due to varus load). In a high energy trauma, there is fracture-dislocation of the medial plateau with soft tissue injuries (meniscus and ACL tear, common peroneal nerve injury). Low energy traumas cause lateral plateau fractures. AP, lateral and oblique radiograph views are helpful; oblique view helps in determining amount of depression. AP view shows depressed articular surface and abnormal joint alignment. Lateral view shows posteromedial fracture lines and abnormal tibial slope.

 


AP and Lateral view showing tibial condyle/plateau fracture

 

Option B. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disease of unknown etiology that affects approximately 1% of the world population, with approximately 50% of adults being unable to work within 10 years of disease onset. The disease involves synovial joints and leads to progressive joint destruction. The knee joint is commonly involved in RA. Severe destruction of the articular cartilage and menisci is a characteristic feature of RA. Bone marrow edema and bone erosion can both also be found, but are less characteristic.

 

 

Option D. Hemarthrosis of Knee Joint: Hemarthrosis is bleeding into a joint cavity. It is best diagnosed with arthrocentesis and synovial fluid analysis. Traumatic injury is the most common cause of hemarthrosis. Non-traumatic hemarthrosis can be caused by bleeding disorders that are either hereditary or acquired. Hereditary bleeding disorders include hemophilia and inherited coagulation factor deficiency disorders. Examples of acquired bleeding disorders include advanced liver or renal disease, vitamin K deficiency, disseminated intravascular coagulation, or anticoagulation medication use. Post-operative recurrent hemarthrosis is frequently associated with total knee arthroplasty. The preferred initial imaging modality is plain film radiology of the involved joint and surrounding bones. If a fracture is not seen but strongly suspected, further evaluation with a CT scan is warranted. MRI may be able to diagnose ligamentous or other soft tissue injuries as the cause of hemarthrosis. Ultrasound (US) can help identify and characterize intra-articular fluid collections. The synovial fluid from a hemarthrosis may appear red, pink, or brown depending on the cause of bleeding. Aspiration of the joint and subsequent analysis can differentiate simple effusion, hemarthrosis, lipohemarthrosis, and septic arthritis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the comminuted fracture of the patella.

choices.text: The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reasons is independently a false statement.
The assertion is independently a false statement, but the reasons is independently a true statement.
Both assertion and reason are true statements
Both assertion and reason are false statements

questions.text:
Assertion: Resting membrane potential is dependent on proteins and phosphate ions.

 

Reason: Diffusion potential can be calculated using Nernst Equation. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are true statements

 

Resting membrane potential refers to the electrical charge difference across the cell membrane of a neuron or other excitable cells when the cell is at rest, meaning it is not actively transmitting signals. This potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions, across the cell membrane.

 

Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

 

 

Where:

 

  • E is the equilibrium potential for the ion.
  • R is the ideal gas constant.
  • T is the absolute temperature (in Kelvin).
  • z is the valence (charge) of the ion.
  • F is Faraday's constant.
  • [Cout]​ and [Cin]​ are the concentrations of the ion outside and inside the membrane, respectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Resting membrane potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions (including proteins and phosphate ions), across the cell membrane.
  • The Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

questions.text: Which is not a branch of facial artery in the face?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mental

 

The first part of the maxillary artery gives rise to the mental artery as a terminal branch of the inferior alveolar artery.

 

The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery that runs a tortuous course through the submandibular region of the face, supplying blood to the muscles of facial expression, submandibular gland, and other structures in the face. The facial artery gives rise to several branches, including the superior and inferior labial arteries, which supply blood to the upper and lower lips, respectively. The lateral nasal artery is a branch of the facial artery that supplies blood to the lateral aspect of the nose.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral Nasal: The lateral nasal artery is a branch of the facial artery that supplies blood to the side of the nose.

 

Option C. Superior Labial: The superior labial artery is a branch of the facial artery that supplies the upper lip and surrounding areas.

 

Option D. Inferior Labial: The inferior labial artery is also a branch of the facial artery, and it supplies the lower lip and surrounding regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mental artery is not a branch of the facial artery. Instead, it is a branch of the inferior alveolar artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery. The mental artery supplies blood to the chin and lower lip.

questions.text: Identify the method of killing shown in the picture below : (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Burking

 

  • Burking is a method of homicidal smothering with traumatic asphyxia.

  • In Burking the assaulter kneels or sits on the chest (traumatic asphyxia) and close the nose and mouth with his hands (smothering)

  • The term 'Burking' is derived from notorious criminal 'Burke', who with his accomplice 'Hare', killed old people by a combination of smothering and traumatic asphyxia, and sold the bodies to the medical school in Edinburgh.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Smothering: This involves blocking the airways by covering the nose and mouth but does not necessarily include the chest compression seen in Burking.

 

Option C. Traumatic asphyxia: This involves compression of the chest, but without the simultaneous smothering of the airways, it does not constitute Burking.

 

Option D. Overlaying: This typically refers to accidental asphyxia, often seen in infants, where a person (usually a caregiver) unintentionally rolls over the child during sleep, causing suffocation. This is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burking involves a combination of smothering and traumatic asphyxia, characterized by chest compression and obstruction of the airways, a method historically associated with the criminal activities of Burke and Hare.

questions.text: A patient displaying lytic lesions on the skull is being considered for a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. What represents a distinctive discovery on electron microscopy among the following options? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Birbeck granules

 

The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histiocytes: While Langerhans cells are a type of histiocyte, the presence of histiocytes alone is not specific to LCH. The defining feature is the presence of Birbeck granules.

 

Option C. Eosinophils: Eosinophils are often present in LCH lesions, especially in eosinophilic granuloma, but they are not a distinctive finding on electron microscopy.

 

Option D. Giant cells: Giant cells may be present in a variety of inflammatory or granulomatous conditions, but they are not specific to LCH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Birbeck granules on electron microscopy is a distinctive and pathognomonic finding in Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

choices.text: Luteal phase LH
Post luteal phase LH
FSH in the follicular phase

questions.text: Which of the following is the best measures ovarian reserve? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH)

 

Explanation:

 

  • Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of pre-antral follicles. It is the best marker of ovarian reserve because it can be tested on any day of the cycle.
  • Values and Interpretation:
    • Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL
    • Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL
    • Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL

 

Tests for ovarian reserve:

 

  • FSH levels: Measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle). High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted.
  • Serum estradiol values: Measured on day 3 of the cycle. Serum estradiol >75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction.
  • Antral follicular count on ultrasound: Counts less than 4-5 on days 2-5 denote poor response to hormones.
  • Inhibin B: Values <40 pg/mL indicate poor reserve.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.

 

Option B. Post luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.

 

Option C. FSH in the follicular phase: While useful, it is less reliable than AMH for assessing ovarian reserve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is the best marker of ovarian reserve as it can be tested on any day of the menstrual cycle and provides a reliable measure of the ovarian reserve.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 528,529, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg435

questions.text:
A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. The risk of which of the following is increased in the newborn? (INICET Nov 2022)

  1. Low APGAR score.
  2. ADHD.
  3. Persistent pulmonary hypertension.
  4. Delayed developmental milestones.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, b, c, d

 

Explanation:

 

a. Low APGAR score: SSRIs in late pregnancy can lead to neonatal adaptation syndrome, impacting the APGAR score.

 

b. ADHD: Some research suggests a potential link between prenatal SSRI exposure and ADHD.

 

c. Persistent pulmonary hypertension: Late-pregnancy SSRI exposure is associated with this risk.

 

d. Delayed developmental milestones: There's some evidence linking SSRIs to delayed milestones, though it's less consistent.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SSRIs during pregnancy are linked to multiple neonatal risks. They may increase the risk of cardiac birth defects, decreased gestational age, spontaneous abortion, decreased birth weight, suboptimal fetal growth, low APGAR scores, autism spectrum disorders, ADHD and persistent pulmonary hypertension (SSRIs and SNRIs).

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 687-688

choices.text: 1-5% of the population can have epileptiform discharges.
Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy.
Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves.

questions.text: True about electroencephalogram (EEG) is all except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.

 

Electroencephalography (EEG) is a key diagnostic tool in the evaluation of neurological conditions, particularly epilepsy. However, it is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures. A patient can have seizures even if their EEG results are normal. An abnormal EEG can provide reassurance of a diagnosis of epilepsy when the clinical context supports it, but a normal EEG does not rule out epilepsy or seizures. Therefore, making an EEG mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1-5% of the population can have epileptiform discharges: This statement is correct. Epileptiform discharges can be present in a small percentage of the general population without necessarily indicating that the individual has epilepsy.

 

Option B. Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy: This statement is correct. Scalp EEG can indeed help localize the origin of epileptic activity, including frontal lobe epilepsy, although it might not always be definitive.

 

Option D. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves: This statement is correct. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) and other forms of encephalopathy can show triphasic waves and slow wave patterns on an EEG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EEG is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures as patients can have seizures even with a normal EEG.

questions.text: What is the reason behind Senile Atrophy? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduced blood supply

 

Senile atrophy is seen when there is a reduced blood supply to a tissue.

 

  • Atrophy is decrease in cell size and/or number due to decreased demand or functional loss.
  • 2 pathways responsible for it: Ubiquitin Pathway (via Proteasomes) and Autophagy (Defense mechanism).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Denervation: Atrophy due to loss of nerve supply is known as denervation atrophy, commonly seen in conditions like poliomyelitis.

 

Option B. Decreased nutrition: This refers to atrophy due to inadequate nutrient supply, leading to cachexia.

 

Option C. Decreased workload: This refers to disuse atrophy, where tissues reduce in size due to inactivity, such as muscle wasting in immobilized limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Senile atrophy is primarily due to reduced blood supply, leading to tissue shrinkage and loss of function with aging.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart disease has equal saturation in all the chambers of the heart? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

 

  • TAPVC is a congenital heart defect where oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins does not reach the left atrium but instead reaches the right atrium, which contains deoxygenated blood.
  • The pulmonary veins drain into the superior vena cava or the inferior vena cava, or both, causing a total mixing lesion. This mixing lesion leads to the oxygenated blood passing to the right ventricle and pulmonary artery, and to the left atrium through the atrial septal defect or the patent foramen ovale, and then to the left ventricle.
  • The left atrium receives blood only from this shunt and not from the pulmonary veins, as all of them are draining to the right atrium.
  • This shunt causes equal saturation of oxygenated blood in all four chambers of the heart since the blood from the right atrium reaches all other chambers.  TAPVC can present with cyanosis, respiratory distress, tachypnea, tachycardia, and poor feeding in neonates.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by echocardiography, which shows the abnormal venous return of the pulmonary veins.
  • Treatment requires surgical repair to establish normal pulmonary venous return and improve oxygen saturation. The surgery should be performed as soon as possible to prevent irreversible pulmonary hypertension and cardiac failure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetralogy of Fallot: Tetralogy of fallot will not have some saturation in all chambers. Remember the x ray finding is “ boot shape heart “

 

Option C. Tricuspid atresia: Tricuspid atresia will have decrease blood flow going from right atrium to right ventricle. So there will be difference in saturation in chambers.

 

Option D. Transposition of great arteries: In this condition the pulmonary artery is attached to the left ventricle & aorta is attached to the right ventricle which leads to parallel circulation. There will be saturation difference.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Circulation (TAPVC), there is equal oxygen saturation in all chambers of the heart due to the complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood in the right atrium.

questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds with which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Globin part of hemoglobin

 

Option B. Globin part of hemoglobin: 2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin. This binding reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, facilitating oxygen release to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Globin part of myoglobin: 2,3-BPG does not bind to myoglobin. Myoglobin, primarily found in muscle tissue, has a higher affinity for oxygen and does not interact with 2,3-BPG.

 

Option C. Heme part of myoglobin: The heme part of myoglobin binds to oxygen directly; 2,3-BPG does not bind to this site or affect myoglobin's oxygen affinity.

 

Option D. Heme part of hemoglobin: While the heme part of hemoglobin is the site for oxygen binding, 2,3-BPG does not bind here. It binds at a separate site on the globin chains to modulate oxygen affinity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin, reducing its affinity for oxygen and facilitating the release of oxygen to tissues. This interaction is crucial for efficient oxygen delivery in response to tissue demands.

questions.text: A surgeon performs an appendicectomy with a grid iron incision. He later converts the incision to Rutherford Morrison incision. Which of the following are cut? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

When the initial Gridiron incision is converted to Rutherford Morrison incision, the external oblique, internal oblique, and transverse abdominis muscles are cut.

 

Gridiron incision is also known as McArthur’s incision. It is a muscle splitting incision used in open appendicectomy.

 

Rutherford Morrison incision is useful in cases where the appendix is para- or retrocaecal and fixed. The lower end of the incision is located over McBurney's point and extends obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary. It involves cutting through the skin, subcutaneous tissues, external oblique, underlying internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and peritoneum along the line of the incision.

 

The Lanz incision is a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, located 2 cm below the umbilicus and centered on the midclavicular-mid-inguinal line.

 

The Pfannenstiel incision is an infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: Which type of sensation is carried by the 2nd order neuron of the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pain

 

The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve is responsible for transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the face to the brain. The second-order neurons in this nucleus relay these sensations to higher brain centers for processing. This pathway is crucial for the perception of painful stimuli and temperature changes, ensuring appropriate responses to potential dangers or injuries.

 

Note -

 

  • The trigeminal nerve has two types of nuclei: a motor nucleus and sensory nuclei.
  • The motor nucleus is singular and located in the pons.
  • The sensory nuclei are more numerous, consisting of three different nuclei distributed within the brainstem:
    • Mesencephalic Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (MNT): This nucleus is situated in the midbrain and is part of the sensory nuclei.
    • Chief Sensory Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (CNT): Located in the pons, this nucleus primarily handles the main sensory functions of the trigeminal nerve.
    • Spinal Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (also referred to as SNT): This extends down to the medulla and is involved with transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the face to the brain.
  • Four nuclei: (3 sensory +1 Motor).
  • General somatic afferent:
    1. Mesencephalic (midbrain & pons): receives proprioceptive fibers from face
    2. Principal (main) sensory (pons): receives touch fibers from face.
    3. Spinal (pons, medulla & upper 2-3 cervical segments of spinal cord): receives pain & temperature sensations from face.
  • Special visceral efferent:

4. Motor nucleus (pons): supplies:

  • Four muscles of mastication (temporalis, masseter, medial & lateral pterygoid).
  • Other four muscles (Anterior belly of diagstic, mylohyoid, tensor tympani & tensor palati).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proprioception: Proprioception is managed by the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus. This nucleus is responsible for sensing the position and movement of the jaw muscles, contributing to reflexes such as the jaw jerk.

 

Option B. Touch: The chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve handles the sensation of touch. This nucleus receives tactile information from the face and transmits it to the brain.

 

Option D. Vibration: Vibration sense is also managed by the chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. This nucleus is involved in processing detailed touch and vibratory sensations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve carries pain and temperature sensations, distinguishing it from the other nuclei responsible for proprioception, touch, and vibration.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient visits his family practitioner for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg. His pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arterial wall compliance

 

Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and it reflects the compliance (elasticity) of the arterial walls. In this scenario, the patient has a high systolic blood pressure and a normal diastolic blood pressure, resulting in an increased pulse pressure of 90 mm Hg (190 mm Hg - 100 mm Hg = 90 mm Hg).

 

Arterial wall compliance refers to the ability of the arteries to expand and contract with each heartbeat, which helps maintain a steady blood pressure. Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, which can cause an increase in systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial contractility: Incorrect. While myocardial contractility can influence blood pressure, it is not directly related to the increase in pulse pressure in this scenario.

 

Option B. Stroke volume: Incorrect. Stroke volume affects cardiac output and overall blood pressure but is not the primary factor in the increase in pulse pressure observed here.

 

Option D. Cardiac output: Incorrect. Cardiac output can affect overall blood pressure, but the specific increase in pulse pressure in this case is more closely linked to decreased arterial wall compliance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, resulting in higher systolic blood pressure and an increased pulse pressure, as observed in the patient.

questions.text: Identify the 2nd generation supraglottic airway device from the options given below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LMA Proseal

 

The LMA Proseal is a second-generation supraglottic airway device. Second-generation devices are designed to be safer than first-generation devices, offering a higher pressure pharyngeal seal and a reduced risk of aspiration. These devices often have two tubes: one for ventilation (airway tube) and another for draining gastric secretions (gastric tube). The LMA Proseal, specifically, features these characteristics, making it a second-generation device.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LMA Fastrach: LMA Fastrach, also known as the intubating LMA, is not categorized as either a first or second-generation device. It is classified as a special LMA due to its unique design, which facilitates difficult intubations.

 

 

Option B. LMA Flexible: The LMA Flexible is a variant of the LMA Classic, which is a first-generation device. It has a flexible airway tube but lacks the features of second-generation devices, such as a high-pressure pharyngeal seal and an additional tube for gastric drainage.

 

 

Option D. Ambu LMA: The Ambu LMA does not have the dual-tube system that characterizes second-generation devices.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

LMA Proseal is a second-generation supraglottic airway device, identified by its two-tube system that enhances safety by reducing the risk of aspiration

questions.text: Which of the following will halter the maturity of collagen?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

Option B. Scurvy:

  • Scurvy is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid).
  • Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen. Without adequate vitamin C, collagen production is impaired, leading to the characteristic symptoms of scurvy, including impaired wound healing and gum bleeding.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Beri-Beri:

  • Beri-Beri is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin B1 (thiamine).
  • Thiamine deficiency primarily affects the nervous system and cardiovascular system and does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Option C. Night Blindness:

  • Night blindness is often associated with a deficiency in vitamin A (retinol).
  • Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision and does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Option D. Rickets:

  • Rickets is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate.
  • Vitamin D plays a role in calcium and phosphate homeostasis, which is crucial for bone health but does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scurvy is the condition that will halt the maturity of collagen because it is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, which is essential for collagen synthesis.

 

Ascorbic acid is necessary for the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues.

 

 

Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are essential for the formation of cross links in the collagen, which gives the tensile strength to the fibers. This process is absolutely necessary for the normal production of supporting tissues such as osteoid, collagen and intercellular cement substance of capillaries.

 

Thus, in ascorbic acid deficiency (Scurvy), collagen is abnormal and the intercellular cement substance is brittle. So, capillaries are fragile, leading to the tendency to bleed even under minor pressure.

questions.text:
An orthopedic surgeon plans to treat a Colle’s fracture. What are the steps involved in applying a cast for the same?(INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Palmar flexion
  2. Traction
  3. Ulnar deviation
  4. Application of plaster of Paris
questions.solution:
Ans. C) II, I, III, IV

 

COLLE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Colles fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corticocancellous junction.
  • It mostly occur in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women.
  • Symptoms and Signs:
    • Fracture of the distal radius, commonly referred to as a Colle’s fracture, is typically the result of a FOOSH injury (Fall on outstretched hand) with wrist in extension.
    • Patients present with swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness, and painful range of motion of the distal forearm.
    • On examination, the classic “dinner fork” deformity (dorsal displacement of the distal fragment and volar angulation of the distal intact radius with radial shortening) may be identified.

 

 

 

  • Complications:
    • Early complications may include median nerve neuropathy, extensor pollicis longus tendon rupture, and compartment syndrome.
    • Late complications may include radiocarpal arthrosis, complex regional pain syndrome, cosmetic changes of the wrist, and fracture malunion or nonunion.
    • Finger stiffness is most common complication.
    • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.
    • Colles fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in upper limb.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Non-displaced extra-articular fractures are relatively stable and are treated non-operatively with a long-arm splint acutely  to allow for swelling, then transitioned to a short-arm cast.
    • The cast is applied on opposite forces to displacement. The position of immobilization is:

 

 

  • Displaced fractures should undergo an attempt at closed reduction followed by immobilization in a long-arm sugar-tong splint acutely.
  • Surgical fixation is indicated for distal radius fractures that fail to meet acceptable alignment criteria.
  • Various methods include closed reduction percutaneous  pinning, external fixation, and open reduction internal fixation (ORIF).
  • Technique of closed manipulation:
    • The muscles of forearm must be relaxed, either by general or regional anaesthesia.
    •  The surgeon grasps the injured hand as if he was ‘shaking hands’.

 

 

 

  • The first step is to disimpact the fragments which have often been driven together.
  • This is achieved by firm longitudinal traction to the hand against the counter-traction by an assistant who grasps the arm above the flexed elbow.
  • The surgeon now presses the distal fragment into palmar flexion and ulnar deviation using the thumb of his other hand.
  • As this is done, the patient’s hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.
  • A plaster cast is applied extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, maintaining

 

Educational Objective:

 

Steps of cast application in Colles fracture are:

 

Traction

↓

Palmar flexion

↓

Ulnar deviation

↓

Application of plaster of Paris

questions.text: On Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining oocysts of size 8-10 µm cysts are visible. Identify the organism? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cyclospora

 

Cyclospora cayetanensis is a coccidian parasite that causes the gastrointestinal disease cyclosporiasis. The organism produces oocysts that are 8-10 µm in diameter, which can be detected by Ziehl-Neelsen staining. The oocysts exhibit a variable acid-fast staining property and can also autofluoresce under ultraviolet light.

 

Cyclospora oocysts have the following characteristics:

 

  • Size: 8-10 µm in diameter.
  • Staining: They show variable acid-fast staining.
  • Autofluorescence: They exhibit blue-green autofluorescence under ultraviolet light.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Isospora: Isospora (now known as Cystoisospora) produces larger oocysts, typically 20-30 µm in size, and contains two sporocysts with four sporozoites each. It does not match the 8-10 µm size described.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium oocysts are smaller, measuring 4-6 µm in diameter, and consistently exhibit acid-fast staining and bright auramine fluorescence. They do not match the size range described.

 

Option D. Microspora: Microspora are a group of spore-forming unicellular parasites that do not fit the description of having 8-10 µm oocysts visible with Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

Plasma contains various components like ions, inorganic and organic molecules that help in the transport of substances across various parts of the body, such as Albumin, globulin, and fibrinogen fractions.

 

  1. Thyroxine is carried by transthyretin, also called thyroid-binding pre-albumin.
  2. Fatty acids are carried by albumin, which is a major carrier protein and osmotic regulator. It also transports hormones, amino acids, vitamins, and steroids.
  3. Hemoglobin binds to haptoglobin, which prevents free hemoglobin from being excreted in the urine.
  4. Heme binds with hemopexin for heme recycling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasma transporters like prealbumin, albumin, haptoglobin, and hemopexin play crucial roles in the transport and recycling of thyroxine, fatty acids, hemoglobin, and heme respectively.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed tumor in the retroperitoneal space? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liposarcoma

 

Liposarcoma is the most commonly observed tumor in the retroperitoneal space. Liposarcomas are malignant tumors that arise from adipocytes and are most frequently located in the retroperitoneum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhabdomyosarcoma: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of muscle origin. While it can occur in various parts of the body, it is more commonly associated with pediatric populations in the neck.

 

Option C. Synovial sarcoma: Synovial sarcoma is a rare type of cancer that tends to arise near large joints but can occur anywhere in the body.

 

Option D. Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors. While they can occur in various parts of the body, including the retroperitoneum, they are not the most frequently observed tumor in this location. It's also important to note that when associated with certain genetic conditions like Neurofibromatosis type 1, they can be seen in multiple areas of the body, but they still don't surpass liposarcomas in frequency in the retroperitoneal space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Retroperitoneal tumors can be benign or malignant and may be of various origins.
  • Mesodermal tumors are the most common malignant retroperitoneal tumors.
  • The order of frequency for primary retroperitoneal malignancy is liposarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, and malignant nerve sheath tumors.
  • Liposarcoma has three histologic varieties, which are well-differentiated and undifferentiated liposarcoma, pleomorphic liposarcoma, and myxoid/round cell liposarcoma.
  • Among the three subtypes, pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while well-differentiated liposarcoma is the least malignant.

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endo-myocardial biopsy

 

An endo-myocardial biopsy is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis.

 

Active myocarditis is characterized by an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate associated with degenerating or apoptotic myocytes.

 

Etiological classification of myocarditis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Magnetic Resonance Imaging: MRI can be used to detect myocardial inflammation and scarring, but it is not the gold standard. It is useful for non-invasive assessment but cannot definitively diagnose myocarditis without histological confirmation.

 

Option C. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP): BNP is a biomarker used to assess heart failure but is not specific or sensitive for diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Option D. LDH1 to LDH2 ratio: This ratio is sometimes used in the context of myocardial infarction but does not have a role in diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endo-myocardial biopsy remains the gold standard for diagnosing myocarditis, as it allows for direct histopathological examination of myocardial tissue.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1064

questions.text: Match the following: (INCET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c

 

Explanation:

 

1. Football sign: This sign is associated with pneumoperitoneum, where an accumulation of gas in the peritoneal cavity gives a silhouette resembling a football on X-ray images.
